questions.text: The following are correct regarding normal placenta except
questions.solution:
• Normally umbilical cord has 3 vessels, 2 umbilical arteries & 1 umbilical vein.(The right umbilical vein disappears)
  • The placenta at term, is almost a circular disk with a diameter of 15-20 cm(Option B) and thickness ranging from 2.5-4 cms at its center(Option C). Placenta with a thickness >4cm is known as placentomegaly.
  • It weighs 500gm(Option A), the proportion to the weight of the baby being roughly 1 : 6 at termQ(At 17 weeks of gestation the weight of the placenta and fetus are equal)
  • Occupies about 30% of the uterine wall.
  • Itpresents two surfaces, fetal and maternal and a peripheral margin.
  • Fetal surface:The fetal surface is covered by the smooth and glistening amnion with the umbilical cord attached at or near its center. At term, about four-fifths of the placenta is of fetal origin.
  • Maternal surface: The maternal surface is rough and spongy. Maternal blood gives it a dull red color. The maternal surface has 10-38 convex polygonal areas known as lobeswhich are limited by fissures. Each fissure is occupied by the decidual septum which is derived from the basal plate. The total number of placental lobes remains the same throughout gestation and individual lobes continue to grow. Some people refer to lobes as cotyledons. This is not correct. A cotyledon or lobule is the functional unit of placenta originating from a main (stem villus primary). The maternal portion of the placenta amounts to less than one-fifth of the total placenta. Only the decidua basalis and the blood in the intervillous space are of maternal origin.
  • Blood vessels: Initially, there are four vessels - two arteries and two veins. The arteries are derived from the internal iliac arteries of the fetus and carry the venous blood from the fetus to the placenta. Of the two umbilical veins, the right one disappears by the 4th month, leaving behind one vein which carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus. Presence of a single umbilical artery is often associated with fetal congenital abnormalities.

Key Takeaway:

  • The placenta at term, is almost a circular disk with a diameter of 15-20 cm and thickness ranging from 2.5-4 cms at its center. Placenta with a thickness >4cm is known as placentomegaly.
  • It weighs 500gm, the proportion to the weight of the baby being roughly 1 : 6 at termQ(At 17 weeks of gestation the weight of the placenta and fetus are equal)
  • Occupies about 30% of the uterine wall.
  • Itpresents two surfaces, fetal and maternal and a peripheral margin.
  • Normally umbilical cord has 3 vessels, 2 umbilical arteries & 1 umbilical vein.(The right umbilical vein disappears)

12 year old with tanner stage 4 breasts

questions.text: Which of the following suggests primary amenorrhoea
questions.solution:
Patients fulfilling any of the following criteria should be evaluated for amenorrhea:

Primary amenorrhoea

  • No menses by age 13 in the absence of growth or development of secondary sexual characteristics
  • No menses by age 15 regardless of the presence of normal growth and development of secondary sexual characteristics

In this case, secondary sexual characteristics depicted by thelarche(breast development) hasn't occurred in the 14 yr old aged female(already crossed the cutoff age of 13 yrs) and hence is suggestive of primary amenorrhea.

Other options:

Option A: She is only 11 years old, we need to wait 2 more years before starting evaluation for amenorrhea

Option B,D: She already has well developed breasts(Tanner stage 4 or 5 suggests well developed breasts) and hence we need to wait till 15 years age before any kind of evaluation

Secondary amenorrhoea

In women who have menstruated previously, no menses for an interval of time equivalent to a total of at least three previous cycles or no menses over a 6- month period

Key Takeaway:

Primary amenorrhoea

  • No menses by age 13 in the absence of growth or development of secondary sexual characteristics
  • No menses by age 15 regardless of the presence of normal growth and development of secondary sexual characteristics

Secondary amenorrhoea

  • In women who have menstruated previously, no menses for an interval of time equivalent to a total of at least three previous cycles or no menses over a 6- month period

choices.text: Levonorgestrel and copper containing intrauterine devices

questions.text: All are long acting reversible methods of contraception (LARC) except:
questions.solution:
Long-acting reversible contraception (LARC) refers to contraceptive methods that provide effective, prolonged birth control while being reversible—meaning that fertility returns promptly after discontinuation. LARC methods are highly effective, with failure rates less than 1% when used correctly, and they are designed to last for extended periods without requiring daily attention. There are two main types of LARC:

  1. Intrauterine Devices (IUDs):
    • Copper IUD (Non-hormonal): A small, T-shaped device made of copper that is inserted into the uterus. It can prevent pregnancy for up to 10-12 years by interfering with sperm mobility and fertilization.
    • Hormonal IUD: This type releases progestin (a hormone similar to progesterone), which thickens cervical mucus and thins the uterine lining, preventing sperm from reaching an egg. It can last from 3 to 7 years depending on the brand. Eg. LNG-IUD, DMPA
  2. Implants:
    • Contraceptive Implant: A small, flexible rod that is inserted under the skin of the upper arm. It releases progestin to prevent ovulation, and it can provide effective contraception for up to 3-5 years.

Key Benefits of LARC:

  • Highly effective: LARC methods are over 99% effective at preventing pregnancy.
  • Low maintenance: Once inserted, they require little to no action from the user, making them convenient.
  • Long-term protection: They offer protection from pregnancy for several years.
  • Reversible: Fertility returns quickly after removal, allowing for future pregnancy planning.

Considerations:

  • Insertion/Removal: LARC methods must be inserted and removed by a healthcare professional.
  • Side effects: Some users may experience side effects such as irregular bleeding, especially in the first few months after insertion.

LARC methods are increasingly recommended due to their effectiveness, safety, and ease of use, making them a popular choice for long-term contraception.

questions.text: A woman with eclampsia is started on magnesium sulphate. What is the first sign of MgSO4 toxicity?
questions.solution:
Monitoring for magnesium toxicity

  • Urine output should be at least 30 ml/hr
  • Deep tendon reflexes(Patellar reflex) should be present
  • Respiration rate should be more than 14/min.
  • Pulse oximetry should be ≥ 96%

Remember

Repeat injection are given only if:

  • Knee jerks are present
  • Urine output > 30 ml/hour
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 14/min

Therapeutic range for MgSO4: 4-7 mEq/l

If MgSOâ‚„ toxicity : Give Calcium Gluconate.

Order of appearance of clinical signs in MgSO4 toxicity:

  • Knee Jerk lost >10meq/l(first sign).
  • Resp depression >12meq/l.
  • Resp paralysis >15meq/l.
  • Cardiac arrest >25meq/l.
  • Oliguria is not a sign of toxicity

"Tips & Tricks"

Key Takeaway:

Order of appearance of clinical signs in MgSO4 toxicity:

  • Knee Jerk lost >10meq/l(first sign).
  • Resp depression >12meq/l.
  • Resp paralysis >15meq/l.
  • Cardiac arrest >25meq/l.

questions.text: Daughter of a woman who received DES during pregnancy is at higher risk for?
questions.solution:
Diethylstilbestrol was previously used to treat Morning sickness in pregnancy.

Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is related with clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina. This is found in those who had history of intrauterine exposure to diethylstilbestrol.

Some associations with DES:

  • Most common anomaly: Vaginal adenosis
  • Most common uterine anomaly: Uterine hypoplasia
  • Most specific anomaly: T shaped uterus
  • Most common carcinoma: Clear cell adenocarcinoma of vagina

Key Takeaway:

  • Some associations with DES:
  • Most common anomaly: Vaginal adenosis
  • Most common uterine anomaly: Uterine hypoplasia
  • Most specific anomaly: T shaped uterus
  • Most common carcinoma: Clear cell adenocarcinoma of vagina

questions.text: According to new WHO guidelines, what is the minimum number of antenatal visits recommended to have a positive pregnancy outcome?
questions.solution:
Recent evidence suggests that the focused antenatal care (FANC) model, which was developed in the 1990s, is associated with more perinatal deaths than ANC models that comprise at least eight contacts between the pregnant woman or adolescent girl and the health care provider.

Minimum number of visits as per MOHFW: 4

  • 1st visit: <12 wks
  • 2nd visit: 14-26 wks
  • 3rd visit: 28-34 wks
  • 4th visit: 36 wks till term

Minimum number of visits as per WHO: 8

Ideal number of visits as per WHO: 12-15

questions.text:
Arrange the steps of D&C in order:
1. Serial dilation
2. Curettage
3. Uterine sound
4. Assessment of uterine size and direction
questions.solution:
Dilation and Curettage (D&C) is a medical procedure in which the cervix is dilated (opened) and the lining of the uterus is scraped or suctioned to remove tissue. It is commonly performed to diagnose or treat certain uterine conditions, such as abnormal bleeding, or after a miscarriage. Here's a brief overview of the steps involved:

Steps of D&C:

  1. Preparation:
    • The patient is positioned on an exam table, typically in the lithotomy position (lying on the back with legs in stirrups).
    • Local or general anesthesia is administered to manage pain and discomfort.
  2. Assessment of uterine size and direction:
    • Using palpation methods
    • Using Uterine sound
  3. Cervical Dilation:
    • The healthcare provider uses a speculum to open the vaginal walls and access the cervix.
    • The cervix is gradually dilated using a series of increasingly larger dilators to allow access to the uterus.
  4. Curettage:
    • A curette (a small, spoon-shaped instrument) or suction device is inserted into the uterus.
    • The provider gently scrapes or suctions the uterine lining to remove tissue.
  5. Tissue Collection:
    • The tissue removed from the uterus is collected and may be sent for laboratory examination if the procedure is done for diagnostic purposes.
  6. Post-procedure:
    • After the procedure, the patient is monitored while the effects of anesthesia wear off.
    • Mild cramping and spotting are common after the procedure.

Recovery:

  • Most patients can go home the same day and resume normal activities after a few days.
  • Follow-up care includes monitoring for any signs of infection or complications.

D&C is often a safe and quick procedure with a relatively short recovery time.

Following are the instruments used:

questions.text: Not a component of Biophysical profile:
questions.solution:
Daily fetal movement count(DFMC) is not a component of Biophysical profile.

Following are the components of Biophysical profile(BPP):

Mnemonic: Remember it as "TBMAN"

choices.text: Includes breathing, movements, tone and Amniotic fluid volume
Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH
Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages
Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia

questions.text: All are true about biophysical profile(BPP) except:
questions.solution:
A Biophysical Profile (BPP) is a prenatal test used to assess the well-being of a fetus, as well as its pH(Option B) typically during the third trimester. It combines an ultrasound evaluation with a non-stress test (NST) to monitor several parameters that indicate the health and functioning of the baby. BPP is often performed if there are concerns about the baby's well-being, such as in high-risk pregnancies, to help assess whether the baby might need early delivery.

Components of Biophysical Profile:

The BPP assesses five key parameters, each scored on a scale of 0 to 2, for a total possible score of 10 points(Option A):

  1. Fetal Heart Rate (Non-Stress Test):
    • Monitors the baby's heart rate in response to its movements.
    • A reactive (normal) result scores 2 points, while a non-reactive result scores 0.
  2. Fetal Breathing Movements:
    • Observation of rhythmic breathing movements in the fetus for at least 30 seconds.
    • Presence of breathing movements scores 2 points; absence scores 0.
  3. Fetal Movement:
    • The baby's body movements (e.g., limb or trunk movements).
    • At least 3 discrete movements in 30 minutes scores 2 points; fewer than 3 scores 0.
  4. Fetal Muscle Tone:
    • Evaluation of the baby's muscle tone by observing flexion and extension of limbs or trunk.
    • Normal muscle tone (e.g., flexion/extension movements) scores 2 points; abnormal or absent tone scores 0.
  5. Amniotic Fluid Volume:
    • Assessment of the amount of amniotic fluid surrounding the fetus.
    • An adequate fluid pocket (at least 2 cm) scores 2 points; insufficient fluid scores 0.

Scoring and Interpretation:

  • 8-10 points: Considered normal, indicating that the baby is likely in good health.
  • 6 points: Borderline; may require further monitoring or follow-up testing.
  • 4 points or lower: Considered abnormal, often prompting immediate intervention, such as additional testing or even delivery if necessary.It is suggestive of acidemia if fetal pH < 7.2(Option D)

Purpose:

The BPP is typically used when there are concerns about fetal distress or complications, such as:

  • Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Diabetes or hypertension in the mother
  • Post-term pregnancy (beyond 40 weeks)
  • Decreased fetal movements

It provides a comprehensive assessment of the baby's well-being and helps guide decisions regarding delivery or further monitoring.

Note: A BPP score of 0 was almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia, whereas a normal score of 8 or 10 was associated with normal pH. An equivocal test result-a score of 6-was a poor predictor of an abnormal outcome. A drop in the BPP score from 2 or 4 down to 0 more accurately predicted an abnormal fetal outcome.

choices.text: Calculated from last day of last menstrual cycle
1st trimester US is the best assessment
In an IVF pregnancy, day of embryo transfer/day of fertilization is needed to calculate POG
Crown-rump length is the best measure in the first trimester

questions.text: Wrong statement regarding POG calculation
questions.solution:
Period of gestation by LMP is calculated from the first day of the last menstrual period.

First, determine the first day of your last menstrual period. Next, count back 3 calendar months from that date. Lastly, add 1 year and 7 days to that date.

Alternate method: Add 9 months 7 days to the first day of last menstrual period to get the EDD(Estimated day of delivery).

For IVF pregnancy date of LMP is 14 days prior to date of embryo transfers (266 days)(Option C) hence we add 266 days to day of embryo transfer to get the EDD.

Ultrasonography in first trimester of pregnancy is more reliable to estimate the gestational age.(Option B) CRL is the best measure in the first trimester ( accuracy +/- 7 days)(Option D)

Ultrasound parameters to measure the Gestational age:

1st trimester: Crown rump length

2nd trimester: Biparietal diameter> Head circumference

3rd trimester: Femoral length

questions.text: A 16 year old presents with absent menses. Examination shows widely spaced nipples, webbed neck, Tanner grade 1 breast development. US shows streak ovaries. Investigation shows- raised FSH, raised LH, reduced estradiol. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is Turner syndrome

Turner Syndrome

Genotype: Most common = 45 XOQ (Loss of one X chromosome is due to Non- dysjunction during meiosis, the X chromosome retained is maternal in origi in most cases).

Mosaics = 45 XO/46 XX or 45 XO/46 XY

  • Gonads: B/L Streak Gonads.(since one single X chromosome is present, so ovaries are not properly formed).
  • Associated with low E2 and high FSH, LH

Other options:

B. Kallmann Syndrome:

Kallmann syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by a failure to start or fully complete puberty, combined with an impaired sense of smell (anosmia). It results from the failure of the hypothalamus to produce sufficient gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), which is essential for the development of secondary sexual characteristics and reproductive function. The condition affects both males and females, leading to delayed or absent puberty and infertility.

  • Key Features: Delayed or absent puberty, infertility, lack of or reduced sense of smell.
  • Cause: Genetic mutations affecting the development and migration of neurons that produce GnRH.
  • Treatment: Hormone replacement therapy (testosterone for males, estrogen and progesterone for females) to induce puberty and maintain secondary sexual characteristics. Fertility treatments may be required to conceive.

C. Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS):

Androgen insensitivity syndrome is a genetic condition in which a person who is genetically male (XY chromosomes) is unable to respond to male sex hormones (androgens). As a result, individuals with AIS develop female physical traits despite having male genetics. There are two types: Complete AIS (CAIS), where the body is entirely unresponsive to androgens and results in a female appearance, and Partial AIS (PAIS), where there is some sensitivity to androgens, leading to varying degrees of masculinization.

  • Key Features: Individuals with complete AIS often have a female appearance, undescended testes, and are typically infertile. In partial AIS, genital ambiguity may occur.
  • Cause: Mutations in the gene responsible for the androgen receptor.
  • Treatment: Management includes hormone therapy, surgery (e.g., for undescended testes), and counseling. Fertility treatments are typically ineffective for CAIS.

D. Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) Syndrome:

MRKH syndrome is a congenital condition in females where the uterus and the upper part of the vagina are underdeveloped or absent, but the external genitalia are normal. It affects the reproductive tract but does not impair the development of secondary sexual characteristics such as breast development or pubic hair. Girls with MRKH typically discover the condition when they do not start menstruating during puberty (primary amenorrhea).

  • Key Features: Absent or underdeveloped uterus and vagina, normal ovaries and external genitalia, primary amenorrhea, and infertility.
  • Cause: The exact cause is unknown, but it is believed to involve disruptions in the development of the Müllerian ducts during embryonic development.
  • Treatment: Management may include surgical creation of a functional vagina (vaginoplasty) and psychological support. Although natural conception is not possible, fertility options like surrogacy using a woman's own eggs can be considered.

questions.text: Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat program, mild to moderate anemia in a patient less than 34 weeks POG is treated using:
questions.solution:
Management of mild-moderate anemia:

  • <34wks: Oral Iron twice dailyà If non compliant/not responding then shift to IV Iron
  • >34 wks: IV Iron

Option A: We give 2 tablets daily(not 3)

Option B: No need of overloading the patient with too much of iron

Option D: We give IV Ferric carboxymaltose(not IM)

Note:

  • Oral route: Ferrous sulphste, Ferrous gluconate, Ferrous ascorbate
  • IM route: Iron sorbitol, Iron polymaltose, Iron dextrose
  • IV Route: Iron sucrose, Ferric carboxymaltose

questions.text: A woman with 35 + 5 wks gestation complains of epigastric pain, headache and blurring of vision. Her BP- 170/110. She is in labor pains. Examination shows 3 cm dilatation, bag of liquor. What is the management?
questions.solution:
This is a case of severe pre eclampsia with features of impending eclampsia:

  • Epigastric pain
  • Headache
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • New onset visual disturbances

Management of PIH/eclampsia

Mild PIH

  • Anti-hypertensive: Role is doubtful. No proven efficacy. Generally bed rest and some diet restrictions are done.
  • Definitive management(as discussed earlier will always be): Termination of pregnancy done at 37 completed weeks of pregnancy.

Severe PIH

  • 1st step in management is seizure prophylaxis-MgSO4
  • Antihypertensives should be given to decrease BP in a controlled manner without compromising the utero-placental perfusion. Aim-Systolic BP should be between-140 to 155 mm of Hg and Diastolic BP should be between 90 to 105 mm of Hg
  • Glucocorticoids-for lung maturation
  • Definitive management is - termination of pregnancy at 34 completed weeks.(Option B and D ruled out) If a pregnant woman comes with severe PIH before 32 weeks = terminate immediately.
  • No role of conservative management(Option A ruled out)

Timing of termination of pregnancy:

  • Mild preeclampsia: >=37 wks
  • Severe pre eclampsia: >=34 wks
  • Impending eclampsia: Terminate immediately
  • Eclampsia: Terminate immediately
  • HELLP syndrome: Terminate immediately

questions.text: Placenta previa will show
questions.solution:
Clinical Features

Symptoms

  • The only symptom of placenta previa is painless, causeless, fresh vaginal bleeding. (Option A ruled out)
  • The classical features of bleeding in placenta previa are sudden onset, painless, apparently causeless and recurrent. In about 5% cases, it occurs for the first time during labor, especially in primigravidae.
  • In about one-third of cases, there is a history of "warning bleeds/sentinel hemorrhage".
  • The bleeding is unrelated to activity and often occurs during sleep and the patient becomes frightened on awakening to find herself in a pool of blood. The bleeding is unassociated with pain unless labor starts simultaneously.

Signs

  • Pallor, if present, will be proportionate to the amount of bleeding.
  • Size of the uterus corresponds to the period of amenorrhoea(Option C ruled out).
  • Uterus is soft and non tender.(Option B ruled out)
  • Malpresentations are common and if it is a cephalic presentation, the head if usually floating.
  • Fetal heart sounds will usually be heard(c.f. abruption). Slowing of the fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis and prompt recovery on release of the pressure is termed Stallworthy'ssign and is suggestive of posterior placenta praevia.

Following are the points of difference between Placenta previa and Abruptio placenta:

questions.text: The appearance of an ovarian mass is given below. This is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
This is a gross specimen showing a cystic structure with hair and mucoid material suggestive of Mature cystic teratoma

Dermoid Cyst(Mature cystic teratoma)

  • Dermoidcyst is a benign
  • Teratomas are the most common germ cell neoplasm.

On the basis of maturity teratoma can be divided into:

A. Mature(Benign)teratoma = dermoid cystMost common benigntumor of ovary in reproductive age group.

  • Most common benign neoplasm diagnosed during pregnancy.
  • Most common Germ cell tumor.
  • It is the commonest tumor to undergo torsion.
  • It frequently arise in association with mucinous cystadenoma:
  • Age for combined tumor is 20-30 years.
  • Age for simple dermoid cyst is 40-50 years.
  • Bilateralin 10% to 15% of cases.
  • Lining epithelium is stratified squamous epithelium(if dermoid cyst undergoes malignant change - Squamous cell Ca is seen).
  • Dermoid cyst usually contain derivatives of ectoderm, endoderm and mesoderm. Mostcommon tissue element in dermoid cyst is ectodermal.

It may attain a size of 20 cms(generally 15 cms)

  • On cross section - they typically show an area of localized growth from which hair projects, teeth and bone are seen. It is called as Rokitansky protuberance or dermoid process.
  • Malignant change in a dermoid cyst occurs in 0.5-2% cases in patients more than 40 Most common malignancy which develops is, squamous cell carcinoma.

B. Immature(Malignant)teratoma

  • Rare, mostly solid, differ from benign teratomas in the component tissue which resembles that observed in the fetus or embryo rather than mature adult tissue.
  • Tumor occur chieflyin prepubertal adolescents and young
  • Tumor grade is correlated with prognosis and extra-ovarian spread.

C. Gross Pathology of Mucinous Cystadenoma:

  • Size: Typically larger than serous cystadenomas, often reaching sizes of 15-30 cm in diameter or more.
  • External Surface: Smooth, often encapsulated with a thick outer wall.
  • Cyst Contents: Multiloculated (containing multiple cysts or chambers) filled with viscous, thick, gelatinous, or mucinous fluid.
  • Color: The fluid inside is usually clear, pale, or light yellow, sometimes with a jelly-like consistency due to mucin.
  • Location: Most commonly found in the ovaries.
  • Borders: Usually well-demarcated and benign, without invasion into surrounding tissue.

D. Gross Pathology of Serous Cystadenoma:

  • Size: Typically smaller than mucinous cystadenomas, often ranging from 5-15 cm in diameter.
  • External Surface: Smooth and thin-walled, usually less thick than mucinous cystadenomas.
  • Cyst Contents: Unilocular or multilocular, with clear, watery, or straw-colored fluid.
  • Color: The fluid is thin and transparent, resembling serum (hence the name "serous").
  • Location: Most commonly arises in the ovaries.
  • Borders: Well-circumscribed and benign, with no signs of invasion.

questions.text:
A woman presents at 6 weeks of gestation. Which of the following signs can be elicited at this gestation?
1. Goodells sign
2. Osiander sign
3. Internal ballotability
4. Lightening
questions.solution:
The Goodell sign refers to a probable sign of pregnancy, characterized by softening of the cervix. A positive Goodell sign occurs due to increased blood flow noticed in the cervix during the first 4 to 8 weeks of pregnancy, which can also give the vaginal part of the cervix a bluish appearance(Chadwick sign).

Osiander's sign

An early indication of pregnancy(at eight weeks) in which pulsation can be felt through the lateral vaginal fornix.

Internal ballottement can be elicited between 16-28th week. The fetus is too small before 16th week and too large to displace after 28th week. However, the test may not be elicited in cases with scanty liquor amnii, or when the fetus is transversely placed.

Lightening - At about 38th week, specially in primigravidae, a sense of relief of the pressure symptoms is obtained due to engagement of the presenting part.

The other signs observed in the 1st trimester are:

  • Isthmus softening: Hegar sign
  • Bluish discolouration of ectocervix: Chadwick sign
  • Regular rhythmic contraction: Palmer sign
  • Asymmetric growth of uterus due to lateral implantation: Piskacek sign

choices.text: Exclude the presence of another fetus

questions.text: Consider the following actions under AMTSL.What is the first thing to be done?
questions.solution:
Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) is a set of steps designed to prevent postpartum hemorrhage by facilitating the delivery of the placenta and reducing uterine bleeding. Here are the key steps in order:

Steps of AMTSL:

  1. First exclude the presence of another fetus before administering any uterotonic
  2. Administration of a Uterotonic:
    • Immediately after the delivery of the baby (within 1 minute), administer a uterotonic drug (e.g., oxytocin 10 IU intramuscularly). This helps the uterus contract and reduces the risk of excessive bleeding.
  3. Controlled Cord Traction (CCT):
    • Once the uterus is well contracted (usually after the uterotonic has been given), apply gentle, controlled traction on the umbilical cord while supporting the uterus with the other hand (known as counter-traction). This aids in the safe delivery of the placenta.
  4. Uterine Massage:
    • After the placenta is delivered, perform uterine massage through the abdomen to stimulate uterine contraction and prevent atony (uterine relaxation), which can lead to hemorrhage.
  5. Examine the Placenta and Membranes:
    • Inspect the placenta and membranes to ensure they are complete and no fragments are retained inside the uterus, which could lead to complications like infection or hemorrhage.

Following are the various drugs that can be used in AMTSL:

choices.text: This is a non stress test
The baseline shows that the fetus has tachycardia
The beat to beat variability is less
This is a uterine contraction graph

questions.text: Image of a NST given. What can be said about this graph?
questions.solution:
Firstly remember, Cardiotocography is done in intrapartum period whereas NST is done in antepartum period

This seems to be a NST graph as it has only fetal heart rate tracing, whereas a CTG graph consists of a fetal heart rate and uterine contraction tracing.(Option D ruled out)

A normal Non Stress Test(NST) is termed reactive and requires two or more accelerations within 20 minutes of beginning the test (American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists).

Accelerations are accepted irrespective of fetal movement.

Before concluding that a test is nonreactive, a 40-minute or longer tracing should be performed.

Here, the heart rate seems to be within 140-160 bpm, which is normal.(Option B ruled out)

Beat to beat variability can be appreciated here.(Option C ruled out)

CTG graph

questions.text: Perimortem c-section is done by
questions.solution:
Perimortem C-section:

Done by: 4th minute of CPR

Completed within: 5th min

Consent: not needed

Incision: Vertical incision

Instruments required: Scalpel and clamp

During a perimortem CS, a midline vertical incision should be made on the upper segment of the uterine corpus to avoid the placenta while avoiding the bowel and the bladder.

choices.text: Cry of baby in the womb
Infection of both vagina and uterus

questions.text: What is Vagitus uterinus?
questions.solution:
Vagitus uterinus is the crying of a foetus from within the uterus following rupture of the membranes.

Option B: Infection of vagina is known as Vaginitis

Option C: Infection of uterus is known as endometritis

Reference: https://journals.lww.com/obgynsurvey/Citation/1957/06000/Vagitus_Uterinus__Crying_in_Utero.34.aspx

Engagement, Descent, Flexion, Internal rotation, Crowning, Extension, Restitution, External rotation

choices.text: Platinum susceptible if recurrence is < 6 months
Platinum susceptible if recurrence is < 6 months
Platinum resistant if recurrence is >12 months
Platinum resistant if recurrence occurs at <6 months

questions.text: True about ovarian cancer recurrence:
questions.solution:
See the chart below:

One of the most significant factors in determining a patient's risk of recurrence is the stage of the cancer at diagnosis:

  • Patients diagnosed in Stage 1 have a 10 percent chance of recurrence.
  • Patients diagnosed in Stage 2 have a 30 percent chance of recurrence.
  • Patients diagnosed in Stage 3 have a 70 to 90 percent chance of recurrence.
  • Patients diagnosed in Stage 4 have a 90 to 95 percent chance of recurrence.

questions.text: What is the age group distribution for vulval cancer
questions.solution:
Vulval Cancer

  • Vulval cancer accounts for 2%-4% of all malignancies of the female genital tract. The women are generally elderly, in the sixth or seventh decade of life. Thirty per cent of cases are older than 70 years, and 40% of cases are between the age of 60 and 70 years.
  • M/C variety- Squamous cell carcinoma
  • Most common symptom of vulval cancer - pruritis
  • Most common site: Labia majora and minora
  • Most common type of spread: Lymphatics(First lympnode involved-Superficial Inguinal lymphnode, and then Deep inguinal LN and femoral group of lymphnodes).
  • For lateral tumors only ipsilateral lympnodes involved whereas for midline leisons, B/L lymphnodes are involved
  • Sentinel lymphnode biopsy is helpful in vulval cancer
  • Most important prognostic factor- Lymph node status.

questions.text: All are causes of uterine dysfunction except
questions.solution:
Nulliparity is a cause of uterine dysfunction, not multiparity.

Uterine contractions may be insufficiently strong or inappropriately coordinated to efface and dilate the cervix. This is termed uterine dysfunction.

Causes of uterine dysfunction:

Reduces the risk of endometrial Ca

questions.text: The non contraceptive uses of oral contraceptives include all except
questions.solution: Reduces the risk of endometrial Ca

questions.text: Hormone secreted by placenta is
questions.solution:
Options B,C: FSH & LH are secreted by anterior pituitary.

Option D: GnRH is primarily produced by Hypothalamus and regulates FSH and LH secretion from Pituitary.

Few points about HCG:

  • Human Chorionic Gonadotrophin(HCG) is a glycoprotein hormone
  • It's alpha subunit is similar to FSH, LH, TSH
  • It's beta subunit is similar to LH

Hence, HCG is structurally and functionally similar to LH.
